articles.headline: Spirit Airlines Wants to Stay Cheap but Not So Tawdry
articles.snippet: Spirit, the no-frills airline that attracts customers and complaints, plans to improve on-time performance and clean up its image.
articles.abstract: Spirit, the no-frills airline that attracts customers and complaints, plans to improve on-time performance and clean up its image.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the airline that had unabashedly advertised its product as a “cheap seat for a cheap-ass.”

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ Is Locking In the Forces That Already Haunt the Global Economy
articles.snippet: Those forces have self-reinforcing, vicious-cycle dimensions that make it a perilous time for the world’s economies.
articles.abstract: Those forces have self-reinforcing, vicious-cycle dimensions that make it a perilous time for the world’s economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, something bad happens, and it creates huge financial market swings and long-lasting economic ripples. The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were an example, as was the 2011 Japanese nuclear disaster.

articles.headline: AstraZeneca Pushes to Protect Crestor From Generic Competition
articles.snippet: The drug maker is trying to get its popular anticholesterol pill approved to treat children who have a rare disease characterized by high cholesterol.
articles.abstract: The drug maker is trying to get its popular anticholesterol pill approved to treat children who have a rare disease characterized by high cholesterol.
articles.lead_paragraph: No more than a few hundred American children have a rare disease characterized by ultrahigh levels of bad cholesterol.

articles.headline: Volkswagen to Pay $14.7 Billion to Settle Diesel Claims in U.S.
articles.snippet: The automaker, federal officials and lawyers for a half-million diesel owners have reached a deal meant to resolve a big piece of the emissions cheating scandal.
articles.abstract: The automaker, federal officials and lawyers for a half-million diesel owners have reached a deal meant to resolve a big piece of the emissions cheating scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen has agreed to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims stemming from its diesel emissions cheating scandal, in what would be one of the largest consumer class-action settlements ever in the United States.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Abortion Ruling Could Create Waves of Legal Challenges
articles.snippet: Monday’s Supreme Court ruling that a Texas abortion law was unconstitutional will prevent the threatened shutdown of clinics in some states, many of which have been operating in a legal limbo.
articles.abstract: Monday’s Supreme Court ruling that a Texas abortion law was unconstitutional will prevent the threatened shutdown of clinics in some states, many of which have been operating in a legal limbo.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Texas to Alabama to Wisconsin, more than a dozen Republican-run states in recent years have passed laws requiring that abortion clinics have hospital-grade facilities or use doctors with admitting privileges at nearby hospitals.

articles.headline: A Single Senator Stymies the Export-Import Bank
articles.snippet: Senator Richard Shelby has held up the nomination of a board member of the bank, blocking $20 billion for American exports.
articles.abstract: Senator Richard Shelby has held up the nomination of a board member of the bank, blocking $20 billion for American exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thursday is an ignominious anniversary for the government agency that helps finance foreigners’ purchases of American exports. Thanks to a single senator, it has been a full year since the 82-year-old Export-Import Bank could approve deals exceeding $10 million, a limit that rules out high-dollar deals on airplanes, power generators, heavy equipment and nuclear reactors.

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ Doesn’t Mean Game Over, but It May Be Just the First Domino
articles.snippet: Yes, Britain’s economy is likely to suffer in the near term, but the most dire effects of the country’s split from the E.U. may be felt on the Continent.
articles.abstract: Yes, Britain’s economy is likely to suffer in the near term, but the most dire effects of the country’s split from the E.U. may be felt on the Continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: This isn’t meant to scare you, but let’s consider the absolute worst-case scenarios of “Brexit.”

articles.headline: Airbnb in Disputes With New York and San Francisco
articles.snippet: The company, despite an aggressive lobbying effort, has not been able to persuade some local legislators to work with it.
articles.abstract: The company, despite an aggressive lobbying effort, has not been able to persuade some local legislators to work with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb has charmed and strong-armed lawmakers around the world to allow it to operate in their communities. But two cities, Airbnb’s hometown, San Francisco, and New York, the service’s largest United States market, have not been so compliant.

articles.headline: A Sea of Charter Schools in Detroit Leaves Students Adrift
articles.snippet: Michigan leapt at the promise of charters 23 years ago, betting that more competition would improve public education. Instead, old problems grew worse.
articles.abstract: Michigan leapt at the promise of charters 23 years ago, betting that more competition would improve public education. Instead, old problems grew worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — On the face of it, Ana Rivera could have had almost any choice when it came to educating her two sons. For all the abandoned buildings and burned-down houses in her neighborhood in the southwest part of this city, national charter school companies had seen a market and were setting up shop within blocks of each other, making it easier to find a charter school than to buy a carton of milk.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Vows to Rip Up Trade Deals and Confront China
articles.snippet: Reading from a script for the second time in two weeks, Mr. Trump hammered away at familiar economic grievances in Pennsylvania, a state crucial to his election chances.
articles.abstract: Reading from a script for the second time in two weeks, Mr. Trump hammered away at familiar economic grievances in Pennsylvania, a state crucial to his election chances.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONESSEN, Pa. — Donald J. Trump vowed on Tuesday to rip up international trade deals and start an unrelenting offensive against Chinese economic practices, framing his contest with Hillary Clinton as a choice between hard-edge nationalism and the policies of “a leadership class that worships globalism.”
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti, Alexander Burns and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: In ‘Brexit’ and Trump, a Populist Farewell to Laissez-Faire Capitalism
articles.snippet: The “Brexit” vote was driven by a sense among older white workers that they have been passed over. The same frustration fuels the candidacy of Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: The “Brexit” vote was driven by a sense among older white workers that they have been passed over. The same frustration fuels the candidacy of Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Boris Johnson: Is this how the era ushered in by Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher finally ends?

articles.headline: VW’s U.S. Diesel Settlement Clears Just One Financial Hurdle
articles.snippet: The carmaker agreed on Tuesday to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims in the United States, but the final financial toll may well be far higher.
articles.abstract: The carmaker agreed on Tuesday to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims in the United States, but the final financial toll may well be far higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen solved one big problem stemming from its diesel emissions deception,  agreeing on Tuesday to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims in the United States.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: House Benghazi Report Finds No New Evidence of Wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: Ending one of the longest, costliest and most bitterly partisan congressional investigations in history, the Select Committee on Benghazi issued its report.
articles.abstract: Ending one of the longest, costliest and most bitterly partisan congressional investigations in history, the Select Committee on Benghazi issued its report.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ending one of the longest, costliest and most bitterly partisan congressional investigations in history, the House Select Committee on Benghazi issued its final report on Tuesday, finding no new evidence of culpability or wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton in the 2012 attacks in Libya that left four Americans dead.
